conversation.content: So, um, have you really gotten rid of, like, half your stuff? That seems, honestly, pretty extreme.

Well, it happened gradually over [shaky voice] about six months. Once I started really looking at what I actually used versus what just sat there collecting dust, the decisions became surprisingly easy.
But what about [anxious] sentimental things? Family heirlooms?
Oh, those are harder, you know, but I kept the truly meaningful ones. Like, I had boxes of old cards I never looked at, so I photographed them and, actually, kept just three that really mattered.
Doesn't your place feel empty now?
Not at all - it feels [yawn] peaceful actually. There's something really calming about having only things you love and use, plus cleaning takes maybe fifteen minutes now instead of hours.
I mean, what about, er, hobbies? Don't you need, well, equipment and supplies for things?
Sure, but I realized I was, hmm, holding onto hobbies I'd abandoned years ago. Like, I had watercolor supplies from 2015 that I kept thinking I'd use someday, but, honestly, I never did.
Did you regret [crying while speaking] getting rid of anything?
Maybe one or two small things, but nothing major. The mental clarity I gained from not having all that stuff weighing on me mentally has been worth any minor regrets.
Okay so, how do you, basically, handle gifts now? People must, um, still give you things.
I've started asking for experiences instead - concert tickets, restaurant gift cards, donations to causes I care about. Most people actually appreciate not having to shop for physical items.
Wait, you [gasp] ask people not to give you presents?
Not exactly - I just share what would make me happiest when people ask. It's about being intentional with what comes into my space rather than accumulating things out of politeness.
But, uh, what about books? I mean, you can't just, like, get rid of books, right?
Books were my weakness too, actually, but I kept maybe thirty favorites and, you know, use the library for everything else now. It's, er, pretty liberating not having to dust hundreds of books.
So, the thing is, doesn't this lifestyle feel, hmm, restrictive? Like you're, basically, always saying no to things?
It's more like saying yes to what matters, honestly. I have more money for travel now, more time because I'm not managing stuff, and, well, more mental space for actual experiences.
How much money do you think you've saved?

Between not buying unnecessary things and, um, selling what I had, probably around eight thousand dollars this year. But really, the time I've gotten back is, you know, even more valuable than the money.
